title: Support for Document Metadata in Query Responses
body:
Hello,

I'm currently using the Llama library for document search in my project. My documents are sourced from multiple files, and when I receive a response to a query, I need to know which file the response was sourced from. Essentially, I want to associate metadata (the source file) with each document and have that metadata returned with the query response.

I attempted to subclass the Document class to include this metadata and used the subclass when adding my documents. However, I found that the Response object doesn't include the original Document object that matched the query.

Could you advise on whether there's a built-in way to achieve this functionality? If not, would you consider adding support for document metadata in the future?

Alternatively, if you could guide me on how to modify the library to suit my needs, I would greatly appreciate it.

Thanks in advance for your assistance!

title: Confusion in the design concept of GPTVectorStoreIndex
body:
I am developing two apps: Index APP for building a knowledge base and Chat APP based on the knowledge base. I found the Milvus Interface is so weird to use(or my bad)

(Index APP) Save node and embedding to Milvus
```
GPTVectorStoreIndex(
    nodes=nodes,
    storage_context=storage_context,
    service_context=service_context,
)
```
**Confusion 1**: It has a return index, but no need to get the return, because Index has been saved to Milvus.

---

(Chat APP) Load index from Milvus (no documents in `index`, but offer access to Milvus)
```
index = load_index_from_storage(
    storage_context=storage_context,
    service_context=service_context
)
```
**Confusion 2**: As long as there is at least one index in index store (you can even insert one manually), the documents in the index is **ALWAYS** the entire Milvus collection. There is no mapping between index and documents, neither even between index and collection name.

---

I build ComposableGraph upon GPTVectorStoreIndex-s.
```
graph = ComposableGraph.from_indices(
    GPTSimpleKeywordTableIndex,
    [
        GPTVectorStoreIndex(nodes_0_20),
        GPTVectorStoreIndex(nodes_20_40),
        ...
    ],
    index_summaries=index_summaries
)
```
**Confusion 3**: Since Milvus is List-based. How could I build a tree-structured index and save it in Milvus?

title: RouterQueryEngine sometimes raises JSONDecodeError during inference
body:
We are using a `RouterQueryEngine` with a chat agent initialized with `create_llama_chat_agent`. Sometimes when we query the agent, `agent.run(query)` raises a `JsonDecodeError`. Sometimes the query executes successfully. The code that raises the error is in `selection.py` in the `SelectionOutputParser->parse(output)` method. 

Sometimes `output` is as follows, which fails in `json.loads(output)` because of the extra `Output:` at the start of the `output` string:
```json
Output:
[{
  "choice": 3,
  "reason": "This choice is most relevant to the question as it specifically mentions the <item>."
}]
```

However, sometimes the value of `output` is valid JSON and the query completes successfully:
```json
[{
  "choice": 3,
  "reason": "This choice is most relevant to the question as it is specifically about <product>."
}]
```

The LLM output that causes this issue is in `llm_selectors.py` in `LLMSingleSelector->_select()`:
```python
prediction, _ = self._llm_predictor.predict( ... )
```

This issue can be solved by providing `prompt_template_str` or `output_parser` to the arguments of `LLMSingleSelector->from_defaults()`. We will proceed down that path, but it would have been nice if the defaults were more robust.

cc: @ali-tractatus

title: Persit GPTSQLStructStoreIndex
body:
When trying to run `load_index_from_storage` on a persisted GPTSQLStructStoreIndex index, i am given an error `ValueError: sql_database must be specified`
The code below is what im using. is there some secret to persisting this? 

The docs dont really cover it and they just give examples of it during runtime, but the problem is the create_engine, SQLDatabase, and GPTSQLStructStoreIndex calls are all way too slow to be used in a real time chat bot so i was trying to save the index to disc for it to remember the schema and then load it back later, which is much faster

```
def save_file(self):
        from sqlalchemy import create_engine
        engine = create_engine(self.connection_string) #slow
        sql_database = SQLDatabase(engine) #slow
        index = GPTSQLStructStoreIndex([], sql_database=sql_database, ) #slow
        index.storage_context.persist(self.index_file_path)

def load_file(self):
        storage_context = StorageContext.from_defaults(persist_dir=self.index_file_path)
        index = load_index_from_storage(storage_context=storage_context)
        self._index_file = index
```

title: Issue retrieving GPTVectorStoreIndex from storage
body:
It seems as though there may be an issue with the V0.6.0 and loading indexes from storage. 

When generating the index for the first time and keeping it in memory, I am able to query the index to produce a summary and it works just as expected. In my instance, this involves looping through all the docs and creating an index for each to later be used in a graph. 

However, when saving the index to storage and reloading it at a later date, an error is produced anytime the index is queried. I have used a separate persist dir for each index which is passed through when loading them back in. 

Here is an example of my setup: 

```python
def load_all_indexes(index_files):
    indexes = []
    for index_file in index_files:
            storage_context = StorageContext.from_defaults(persist_dir=index_file)
            index = load_index_from_storage(storage_context = storage_context,  service_context=service_context)
            indexes.append(index)
    return indexes
```
```python
def create_summaries(indexes):
    summaries = []
    for index in indexes:
        retriever = index.as_retriever()
        query_engine = RetrieverQueryEngine.from_args(retriever, response_mode='tree_summarize')
        summary = query_engine.query("What is a summary of this document?")
        summaries.append(str(summary))
    return summaries
```
   
Here is an example of the error produced: 
    
 ```
/miniconda3/lib/python3.10/site-packages/llama_index/indices/vector_store/retrievers.py", line 90, in <listcomp>
    self._index.index_struct.nodes_dict[idx] for idx in query_result.ids
KeyError: 'cdb2c18c-b0d3-4af6-973d-0b0b69ff5ddd'
```

title: Need Clarity regarding workflow
body:
```
# max LLM token input size
max_input_size = 1024
# set number of output tokens
num_output = 256
# set maximum chunk overlap
max_chunk_overlap = 20

prompt_helper = PromptHelper(max_input_size, num_output, max_chunk_overlap)

documents = SimpleDirectoryReader('/your/pdf/location/').load_data()

service_context = ServiceContext.from_defaults(
    llm_predictor=llm_predictor,
    embed_model=embedding_llm,
    prompt_helper=prompt_helper
)

index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex.from_documents(documents, service_context=service_context)

index.save_to_disk('embedding.json')

index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex.load_from_disk('embedding.json',service_context=service_context)

query = "question about embedded document"

answer = index.query(query)
```

1. Is there a limitation about how many files/ size for `documents`?
2. Does `max_input_size` and `num_output` depends on LLM? What are values for text-davinci-003 and GPT-4?
3.  `index` is a vector database. When we save it in json format, we save it as a dictionary. Can we save it as a database?
4. When we use `load_from_disk` is there a memory limitation? Do we load in RAM?
5. `answer` makes api calls to OpenAPI. During this what information is sent and received? I am guessing some nodes are parsed (like k=3 or 5) from index and sent to OpenAI. How do we select these nodes?

title: How to migrate index files generated in 0.5.x to 0.6.x?
body:
We save and load index files using following code in 0.5.x:

```
documents = SimpleDirectoryReader("my_folder").load_data()
index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex.from_documents(documents)
index.save_to_disk("index.json")

# load from index.json
index = GPTSimpleVectorIndex.load_from_disk("index.json")
```

But in 0.6.x version, there's no `load_from_disk` method. How can we load the old `index.json` file and convert it to the new storage format? We tried to use `load_index_from_storage` directly but it apparently could not find `docstore` and `index_store` files.

We could not find any migration guide for this. Could anyone help with this problem?

title: Modify the BaseGPTIndex delete function to call docstore delete to delete the metadata.
body: The reason is that there is a bug where the docstore metadata will not delete the doc_id when calling delete. This code change has been verified and fixes the issue. raise_error is set to False, because the doc_id might not be in "docstore/data", but it would be in "docstore/metadata".

title: GraphToolConfig is gone
body:
Hi, thank you for this awesome project!
After upgrading to 0.6.0, I noticed that while https://github.com/jerryjliu/llama_index/blob/6330d3522d38a487b833e4debee4b274ba7362e2/llama_index/langchain_helpers/agents/__init__.py still mentions `GraphToolConfig`, it does not exist anymore in https://github.com/jerryjliu/llama_index/blob/v0.6.0/llama_index/langchain_helpers/agents/tools.py

I am investigating it myself right now but not yet sure how to migrate my code (Chatbot Tutorial) to the new version.

Thanks for any pointers!

title: Configure LLM to use while querying
body:
I know for building the index we can configure the LLM like below:
```
llm_predictor = LLMPredictor(llm=OpenAI(temperature=0, model_name="text-davinci-003"))
prompt_helper = PromptHelper(max_input_size, num_output, max_chunk_overlap)
service_context = ServiceContext.from_defaults(llm_predictor=llm_predictor, prompt_helper=prompt_helper)
index = GPTVectorStoreIndex.from_documents(
    documents, service_context=service_context
)
```

But how can I configure the LLM for querying?
```
query_engine = index.as_query_engine()
response = query_engine.query("What did the author do growing up?")
```

**Will the LLM be same for both querying and indexing?
I want to use different LLM for indexing the data, then load the index and use different LLM to get the response of the query.**

```
storage_context = StorageContext.from_defaults(persist_dir="./storage")
index = load_index_from_storage(storage_context)
```

Is it possible?

title: How can I create a index that allows me to search across csv and txt data?
body:
How can I create an index that allows me to search and give results based on the different data sources accurately? 
Right now, just using a GPTVectorStore doesn't give me the correct results from the csv file when I ask it to query the average data for a column.

title: I want to use Llama-index for document classification. How can I use multiple indexes with it?
body:
Like I got two PDF files in different directories. I load them with the following:
`doc1 = SimpleDirectoryReader('file1').load_data()`
`doc2 = SimpleDirectoryReader('file2.').load_data()`

Then I created indexes for each:
`index1 = GPTTreeIndex.from_documents(doc1)`
`index2 = GPTTreeIndex.from_documents(doc2)`
`index1_summary = "<summary1>"`
`index1_summary = str(summary1)` 

> same done for index2

`all_indices = [index1, index2]`
`index_summaries = [index1_summary, index2_summary]`

`graph = ComposableGraph.from_indices(GPTTreeIndex, all_indices, index_summaries=index_summaries)`

`index = ComposableGraph.load_from_disk("graph.json")`
`query_configs = [
    {
        "index_struct_type": "simple_dict",
        "query_mode": "default",
        "query_kwargs": {
            "similarity_top_k": 3,
            "response_mode": "tree_summarize"
        }
    },
]`

`response = index.query(text, query_configs=query_configs)`

is this approach correct or do I have to make changes? Can this classify both the indexes and queries asked related to them?
Thanks!

title: confused about requirement to recreate original service context exactly when re-loading index from disk
body:
Hi: I'm a little confused by the new (0.6.0) API re. creating and then re-loading an index.  Specifically this comment:

> NOTE: If you had initialized the index with a custom ServiceContext object, you will also need to pass in the same ServiceContext during load_index_from_storage.

seems to be saying that if I create a custom service context then I must recreate that exact same service context every time I reload the index.  In fact, I am getting the same response (to any given query) whether I recreate the original service context and pass it to load_index_from_storage() or not.  Also, per pre-0.6.0 examples I had the impression that the service context could be deliberately altered: eg. I could create an index with (notionally) gpt-3.5-turbo, but then load it with gpt-4.  That works (doesn't throw an exception, even though the service contexts are different), but also doesn't seem to affect the responses.  Am I missing something obvious?  Thanks!
